Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Bringing a dynamic, stochastic, and computational, understanding to subjective probabilities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
We rely on the probability judgments of experts and laypeople every day. Space shuttles are launched not only on the basis of weather forecasts, but also on an engineer's subjective opinion that a part will or will not fail. Military missions and political policies are put in place using intelligence analysts' beliefs that an event will occur or has occurred. Without doubt the use of probability judgments to make decisions makes the accuracy of subjective probabilities of utmost importance. Indeed the accuracy of subjective probabilities has been well studied in the cognitive and decision sciences. Yet, an equally valuable aspect of subjective probabilities is the amount of time it takes judges to formulate their estimates. Clearly, the time a judge takes to make a probability judgment has external costs to both the judge and the decision maker. Yet, little is known about the internal time course of subjective probability judgments. Consequently, the impact these external costs have on subjective probabilities and their accuracy is not known.

In this project the Principal Investigator pursues research examining how variables external to the judge (e.g., time pressure; rewards and penalties) and internal to the judge (e.g., attention and sequential effects) impact the time course and accuracy of subjective probabilities. A general framework called Judgment Field Theory will integrate how these internal and external variables impact probability judgments. Moreover, the framework offers a cognitive account of how different descriptions of the same event (e.g., Lance Armstrong will win the race vs. Lance Armstrong won?t lose the race) change how judges evaluate the likelihood of an event occurring and how this evaluation changes as a function of time.

The broader impacts of the research are three-fold. First, the research will help in the development of methods to evaluate the accuracy of subjective probabilities. These methods can ultimately be used to improve the accuracy of judges. Second, the theoretical framework will be used in the development of an undergraduate psychological methods course curriculum that infuses a traditional methods course with techniques of cognitive modeling. Finally, a broader impact is the outreach to and integration of a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students into cognitive science at MSU.

An overall goal of this research has been to develop a more comprehensive theory of how judges describe their beliefs and how time moderates the accuracy of those judgments. There were three branches of research centered around this goal.

 

The first branch mapped out how the accuracy of confidence judgments changes as people take more time. It is grounded in two-stage dynamic signal detection theory (2DSD; Pleskac & Busemeyer, 2010). The theory describes the process by which people make choices and estimate their confidence in those choices. These situations abound from eyewitnesses identifying an individual in a line up to intelligence analysts making a prediction to students estimating their confidence in a response on a test.  According to 2DSD, to make a choice, people sequentially sample information about the possible alternatives and integrate that information as evidence. Once a threshold of evidence is reached a decision is made accordingly (Figure 1). This basic drift-diffusion process gives a good account of choice and response time data, but it had previously not been able to explain confidence judgments. 2DSD, however, changed this. It assumes that judges continue to accumulate evidence after the choice (post-decisional evidence accumulation). Judges use all of the evidence to then make a confidence judgment.

2DSD gives a good description of a range of phenomena and makes several strong new predictions. One strong prediction is that if judges simply take a little more time to estimate their confidence then the accuracy of those confidence judgments will grow. Despite 50 years of work on how to improve the accuracy of confidence judgments, this simple strategy (take more time) has never been proposed or investigated. We have found strong support for the general prediction (Figure 2). However, and importantly, the results form our studies have led to some important modifications to the model and the assumed process of evidence accumulation. For instance, we have found that as people accumulate evidence it also decays in memory. This decay process has interesting consequences: it means confidence in incorrect choices will show the biggest change over time. What this means is that with just a little more time (even just 1 second) people are much more likely to identify an incorrect choice or prediction.

The second branch used 2DSD to investigate if changes in the information after a choice has been made or feedback impact how post decisional evidence is accumulated and ultimately affect confidence judgments? We have shown that changes in the information after making a choice as well as feedback are integrated into the confidence judgment. But, importantly new or changes in the information does not shut down post-decisional processing.

We have also shown how the act of making a choice changes the confidence we have. Surprisingly, 2DSD and other models directly assume that act of making a choice does not affect how we accumulate evidence and thus predict not change in confidence judgments. Instead we find strong empirical support for an alternative model based on quantum probability theory. Within this framework choices are modeled as an active measurement process, which means making a choice impacts the confidence people have, creating an interference effect.

The third branch investigated how people extract information from descriptions of hypotheses to estimate the probability of the events occurring. In particular, we showed how the context in which a hypothesis is described changes how we interpret the evidence in support of the event occurring.
